name: Breaking the binary
description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

key_work.title: Breaking the binary
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: An unexpected mainstream success, Orlando is a landmark work in feminist and LGBTQIA+ cinema, and Swinton’s binary-breaking performance has helped define her persona, allure and influence ever since.

constellations_primary.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_primary.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

end.title: Orlando
end.creator_credit: Sally Potter, Dien van Straalen, Sandy Powell, Christopher Sheppard, Sigma Pictures, Ben van Os and Jan Roelfs
end.headline_credit: France, Italy, Netherlands, Russia and United Kingdom, 1993
end.brief_description: In 1600, nobleman Orlando (Tilda Swinton) inherits his parents’ house, thanks to Queen Elizabeth I (Quentin Crisp), who commands the young man to never change.

constellations_other.name: Sandy, Swinton, Shakespeare and Derek
constellations_other.description: Tracing costume designer Sandy Powell's ongoing connections with Tilda Swinton, William Shakespeare and Derek Jarman.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: The ‘Breaking the binary’ display in Goddess features the costumes that Tilda Swinton wore in her binary-busting portrayal of the gender-fluid, time-travelling nobleperson. The film was a landmark of LGBTQIA+ 90s cinema and queered the British costume drama.

end.title: Suspiria
end.creator_credit: Brad Fischer, David Kajganich, Francesco Melzi d'Eril, Gabriele Moratti, Luca Guadagnino, Marco Morabito, Silvia Venturini Fendi and William Sherak
end.headline_credit: Italy and United States of America, 2018
end.brief_description: A darkness swirls at the center of a world-renowned dance company, one that will engulf the troupe’s artistic director, an ambitious young dancer and a grieving psychotherapist. Some will succumb to the nightmare, others will finally wake up.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

constellations_other.name: Antiques Horrorshow
constellations_other.description: Rummage through this assortment of props and antiques in horror on screen, discovering valuable connections between them.

links.description: In Luca Guadagnino’s Suspiria, Tilda Swinton plays both female and male roles. She was transformed into the 82-year-old male psychoanalyst through prosthetics in a makeup process that took four hours a day. Critics praised Guadagnino for casting a woman as the film’s only significant male role.

start.title: Suspiria

end.title: Suspiria
end.brief_description: From the moment she arrives in Germany to attend the prestigious Tanz Academy, American ballet-dancer Suzy Bannion (Jessica Harper) senses that something horribly evil lurks within the walls of the age-old institution.

constellations_other.name: Over the Technicolor rainbow
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores the beginning and legacy of Technicolor and was created by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies students Adam Virgona and Kristian Vass.

constellations_other.name: The Suspense Constellation
constellations_other.description: An exploration of music in suspense works.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: Guadagnino’s introduction of Swintons’s Dr. Josef Klemperer is one of several changes made to Dario Argento’s original Suspiria, the film follows a ballet student who enrols at a dance academy run by witches. Argento wasn’t impressed by the remake, saying it “it betrayed the spirit of the original film”.

links.description: Almost three decades after appearing as the Orlando in Sally Potter’s 1992 British period drama fantasy film based on Virginia Woolf’s novel, Tilda Swinton entered the Marvel Cinematic Universe as an androgynous Celtic version of the traditionally male character Ancient One.

end.title: Caravaggio
end.creator_credit: Sarah Radclyffe, Channel 4 Television and Derek Jarman
end.brief_description: As influential Italian artist Caravaggio dies in exile in 1610, he recalls his short life, from his childhood to his initial artistic failures to his later triumphs as he catches the eye of a sympathetic cardinal to his destructive relationship with a dashing gambler.

constellations_other.name: Sandy, Swinton, Shakespeare and Derek
constellations_other.description: Tracing costume designer Sandy Powell's ongoing connections with Tilda Swinton, William Shakespeare and Derek Jarman.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: Swinton’s first film was Caravaggio, made with the Derek Jarman, the English filmmaker, artist, author and gay rights activist. Swinton collaborated with Jarman continuously over the next eight years, appearing in all his subsequent films until his death from AIDS related complications in 1994.

start.title: Caravaggio
start.creator_credit: Sarah Radclyffe, Channel 4 Television and Derek Jarman
start.brief_description: As influential Italian artist Caravaggio dies in exile in 1610, he recalls his short life, from his childhood to his initial artistic failures to his later triumphs as he catches the eye of a sympathetic cardinal to his destructive relationship with a dashing gambler.

end.title: Transparent

video_links.name: Transparent Season 1 - Official Trailer | Prime Video

end.brief_description: An LA family with serious boundary issues have their past and future unravel when a dramatic admission causes everyone’s secrets to spill out.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: Tilda Swinton has curated an exhibition of photography inspired by Virginia Woolf’s book Orlando, which has inspired Swinton since she starred in the film. It features 11 artists including trailblazing multimedia artist and activist Zackary Drucker, who also worked as a producer on the award-winning Transparent.

start.title: Transparent

video_links.name: Transparent Season 1 - Official Trailer | Prime Video

end.title: Hustlers
end.creator_credit: Lorene Scafaria, Jessica Pressler, Adam McKay, Benny Medina, Chelsea Barnard, Elaine Goldsmith-Thomas, Gloria Sanchez, Jennifer Lopez, Jessica Elbaum, Will Ferrell and Nuyorican Productions
end.brief_description: A crew of savvy former strip club employees band together to turn the tables on their Wall Street clients.

constellations_other.name: Ladies who own the narrative
constellations_other.description: Despite the lag in making it in mainstream cinema, female action heroes can actually be traced back to the late 19th century in early magic lantern performances of Jane Conquest, who saved both her child and a ship full of men.

constellations_other.name: Aquaman VFX
constellations_other.description: As well as becoming a global box-office sensation, Aquaman (2018) featured groundbreaking visual effects from Australian companies such as Method Studios.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Female villains, anti-heroes and scammers
constellations_other.description: Mrs. Appleyard (Natalie Dormer) Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) conceals her dark past by creating a new identity for herself as the Headmistress of the renowned finishing school Appleyard College. Explore how Mrs. Appleyard fits into a cluster of famous female villains and anti-heroes on screen.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: Transparent was criticised for casting Jeffrey Tambor, a cisgender, heterosexual man, as a trans woman. However the film also featured several transgender actors such as Trace Lysette (“Shea”) who came out publicly through her role and made her major feature debut in Hustlers.

end.title: Disclosure
end.creator_credit: Sam Feder, Amy Scholder, Bow + Arrow Entertainment, California Humanites, Disclosure Film, Field of Vision, Fork Films, Independent Film Producers (IFP), JustFilms / Ford Foundation, Avram Finklestein and Sofia Midon
end.brief_description: An investigation of how Hollywood’s fabled stories have deeply influenced how Americans feel about transgender people, and how transgender people have been taught to feel about themselves.

constellations_other.name: Welcome to Chechnya: tales through time
constellations_other.description: Documentary Welcome to Chechnya used ground-breaking deep fake technology to hide the identities of LGBTQ+ people fleeing a government-orchestrated genocide in Chechnya.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

constellations_other.name: Speaking for herself
constellations_other.description: This constellation traces some critical ways that women have used the moving image as a way of speaking truth to power.

links.description: Both Zackary Drucker and Tracey Lysette feature in the groundbreaking documentary Disclosure, which takes in-depth look at Hollywood’s depiction of transgender people and the impact of their stories on transgender lives and American culture.
